title: Alan Shearer explains why Liverpool could run away with the league this season

BBC pundit Alan Shearer believes Liverpool could win the Premier League comfortably this season thanks to Manchester City's struggles in defence.

Jurgen Klopp's side beat Leicester City 2-1 on Saturday thanks to a dramatic last-minute penalty from James Milner, while City surprisingly slumped to a 2-0 loss at home to Wolves on Sunday, leaving Liverpool eight points clear at the top of the table.

Liverpool have never won the Premier League, but came agonizingly close last season when they finished just a point behind City, and Shearer believes this could well be the Reds' time to win their first top flight title since 1990.

(Image: Getty Images)

Speaking to the Sun Shearer said: "With less than a quarter of the season gone, we know that it is too early to sat City's title challenge is over.

"It won't be plain-sailing for Jurgen Klopp's side, who have plenty of tests to come, but they look well placed and will have learned from last year.

"City are by no means out of the title race but Guardiola desperately needs his defenders back.

"And if they cannot sort themselves out defensively, then the Premier League title will be heading to Liverpool."

City received a blow early in the season when key centre-back Aymeric Laporte was ruled out until at least January after suffering a knee injury against Brighton in January.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Shearer believes the loss of Laporte, plus Vincent Kompany moving on in the summer, has cost City dear.

"Having looked all at sea losing 3-2 at Norwich, they were once again made to pay for not replacing Vincent Kompany in the summer," added Shearer.

"Nicolas Otamendi and Fernandinho started at the Etihad and were all over the place."

After the international break Liverpool take on bitter rivals Manchester United at Old Trafford while City travel to in-form Crystal Palace .
description: Manchester City's shock 2-0 loss to Wolves ensured the Reds finished the weekend eight points clear at the top of the table
